column4: Apparently it's v1.98, but it's still linux; but at least I've gotten past the error
You probably want to use a distributed revision controll system like git or bzr.
Can I keep my code private?
Yes.
Thanks a bunch, I'll look into the rest myself
You're welcome.
Not working out as planned. It appears that I require a server, and I don't think I can get into the trouble of setting one up
You don't need a server, that's part of the advantage of using a distributed RCS.
Then how would I share the code between computers?

Create a repository on the desktop, do some work and make some commits. Pull that repository to the laptop, either over the network or with a flash drive, do some work on the laptop and make some commits, pull back to the desktop via network or flash drive.

Networking doesn't work for some reason, and I'm not exactly concerned with version management, simply code transfer from one place to another, though git seems like a good idea in the future. Anyway I can get networking to work or UbuntuOne? I'm having problems with those, and thinking of them as my best solution
How are you trying to transfer the file over the network? What problem are you having with that specifically?
I can't see my computer hooked up to the network and vice versa
Though my laptop seems to recognize my router
I can't see my computer hooked up to the network means nothing to me. How are you trying to "see" it?
Sorry about that. I opened up a window from the main menus under Places > Network
And all it says is Windows Network, from me trying to set up Samba, I assume
Sorry about that, upon second inspection, it doesn't seem that it works on my laptop either. How would I go about setting up networking?
You won't see your computer there untill you turn on file sharing with samba by right clicking a directory you want to share, then selecting "sharing options".
If you want help with the Ubuntu one side of things try #ubuntuone.
Thanks again. Wish I could spend less time trying to figure out how to use Ubuntu and more time using it
You're welcome.
Sorry for the trouble, still no luck. Any tutorials out there on networking?
